title: Formal grammar
summary: In formal language theory, a grammar (when the context is not given, often called a formal grammar for clarity) describes how to form strings from a language's alphabet that are valid according to the language's syntax. A grammar does not describe the meaning of the strings or what can be done with them in whatever contextâ€”only their form. A formal grammar is defined as a set of production rules for such strings in a formal language.
